title: generated codemeta.json
body: I'm an intern with ropensci working with @sckott and @cboettig to improve package metadata in the ropensci suite. For this package, I've added applicationCategory and keywords (as advised by Tony Fischetti) to the DESCRIPTION file. Generated codemeta.json file from updated DESCRIPTION by running write_codemeta()

repo.description: Assertive programming for R analysis pipelines
repo.name: assertr

title: Fix for missing rownames in violations
body:
When using predicates from `assertive`, I will sometimes get an error (running error, not data error). It seems to happen when the index.of.violations passed to `make.assertr.assert.error` is a named vector which contains NAs. The most common example I have is as follows, but it happens any time an error is thrown because of an NA.

```r
statedata <- dataframe(name = state.name, area = state.area, stringsAsFactors=FALSE)
assertr::assert_(statedata, assertive::is_not_na, "name")
## <<Works fine>>

statedata$name[4] <- NA
assertr::assert_(statedata, assertive::is_not_na, "name")
## Error in data.frame(index = index.of.violations, value = offending.elements) :
## row names contain missing values
```
But then after explicitly setting rownames in `make.assertr.assert.error`, we get:

```r
assertr::assert_(statedata, assertive::is_not_na, "name")
# Column 'name' violates assertion 'assertive::is_not_na' 1 time
#   index value
# 1     4  <NA>
```

title: Demonstrate use of `magrittr` functional sequences
body:
Hi Tony, 

Love your package, and just wanted to highlight a really neat way to use it with the `magrittr` package's functional sequences. 

Tommy
